questions.text: A patient is asked to do incentive spirometry after his surgery. Which of the following muscles would he use while expiring into the device shown?
questions.solution:
The internal intercostal muscles are the muscles of expiration. 

The device shown in the image is an incentive spirometer. It is a device used to help your lungs recover after surgery or a lung illness.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an accessory muscle of inspiration?
questions.solution:
Latissimus dorsi is not an accessory muscle of inspiration. It is an accessory muscle of expiration.

Accessory muscles of inspiration:

  • Sternocleidomastoid
  • Scalene muscles
  • Serratus posterior and anterior
  • Errector spinae
  • Pectoralis major and minor

Breathing involves changing the thoracic volume by altering the vertical, transverse, and anteroposterior dimensions of the thorax. The diaphragm is the key muscle in respiration.

Serratus posterior superior elevates the ribs, hence aiding in inspiration. Serratus posterior inferior depresses the ribs. It is a muscle aiding in expiration.

questions.text: Which of the following do not elevate the ribs?
questions.solution:
Serratus posterior inferior does not elevate the ribs.

The muscles of inspiration help increase the diameters of the thoracic cavity by elevating the ribs. Serratus posterior inferior is an accessory muscle of expiration. The muscles of expiration help in the depression of the ribs. 

Mnemonic: SIT-Q depressors that work along with anterior abdominals for expiration:

  • Serratus posterior inferior
  • Internal intercostals
  • Transversus thoracis
  • Quadratus lumborum

questions.text: You are interpreting the lateral neck X-ray of a patient who has multiple bruises on his face and neck. To look for tracheal injuries, you will start looking from which level?
questions.solution: The trachea starts at the level of the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage at the level of the C6 vertebra.

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the trachea bifurcate?
questions.solution:
The trachea bifurcates at the lower border of T4 vertebra.

The trachea is 10 - 12 cm long and has 2 parts:

  • Upper cervical
  • Thoracic(in superior mediastinum) 

Note: Although Gray's Anatomy 41st Ed states that the tracheal bifurcation is at T6, we choose to stick with T4 as multiple other textbooks give the answer as T4.

questions.text: Left bronchus crosses esophagus at ________
questions.solution:
The left bronchus crosses the esophagus at 28 cm from the upper incisor teeth.

Normally esophagus shows 4 constrictions at the following levels measured from upper incisors:

  • Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx (15 cm from the incisor teeth)
  • Crossed by arch of aorta (23 cm from the incisor teeth)
  • Crossed by left bronchus (28 cm from the incisor teeth)
  • It pierces the diaphragm (40 cm from the incisor teeth)

questions.text: You are asked to do thoracentesis for a patient with mild pleural effusion on the left side. You are being cautious while inserting a needle in the left midaxillary line of the patient. You would not insert the needle below which level so as not to damage the surrounding structures?
questions.solution:
The inferior margin of the pleura in the midaxillary line is at the level of the 10th rib. So, while doing thoracentesis you would not go below this level. It is done in the 8th or 9th intercostal space so as not to damage the surrounding structures.

questions.text: You are asked to mark the oblique fissure of the lung on a cadaver. Which of the following landmarks will not touch the line while drawing surface markings for this fissure?
questions.solution:
The surface marking of the oblique fissure of the lung will not touch 4th costal cartilage.

On either side, the upper and lower lobes of the lung are separated by the oblique fissure.

This can be marked by a line that runs anteroinferiorly from the posterior end of the 4th rib (the spinous process of the T3 vertebra), crosses the 5th rib in the mid­axillary line, continues inferiorly, crossing either the 6th intercostal space/ 7th rib on the right or the 5th rib/ 5th intercostal space on the left, on both sides at the mid­clavicular line.

The left oblique fissure is located at a higher level and courses more vertically than the right oblique fissure.

questions.text: A young man is rushed to the emergency department after suffering a stab wound over the chest wall. The entry wound is present on the left side in the mid-clavicular line. The lung is likely to not be injured if the entry wound is below which level?
questions.solution:
The lower border of the lung in the midclavicular line is at the level of the 6th rib. Hence, if the entry wound is below this level, the lung is probably not injured.

questions.text: What does the pleural cupola refer to?
questions.solution: The dome-shaped layer of parietal pleura lining the cervical extension of the pleural cavity is called cervical pleura/pleural cupola/dome of pleura.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with cough, haemoptysis, and unexplained weight loss. CT-scan revealed a ​tumor in the right lung invading the mediastinal pleura. The patient is likely to experience referred pain in which of the following regions?
questions.solution:
The pain from mediastinal pleura is referred to the side of the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the mediastinal part of the right lung?
questions.solution:
Superior vena cava is related to the mediastinal part of the right lung.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is a posterior relation to the root of the right lung?
questions.solution:
The vagus nerve is posterior to the root of the lung.  

The roots of the lung are at the level of T5-T7 vertebral bodies. The phrenic nerve is anterior to the root of the lung.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked 'A' in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The area marked 'A' is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung.

The diagram shown is of the right lung, identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum.

questions.text: Which is the most superior structure at the hilum of the left lung?
questions.solution:
The sequence of structures at the left hilum superior to inferior is: (Mnemonic: 'ABV')

  • Pulmonary artery,
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The sequence of structures at the right hilum superior to inferior is: (Mnemonic: 'BABV')

  • Superior lobar (eparterial) bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.text: Which is not a lobe of lungs?
questions.solution:
Lingula is not a lobe. It is a small process that is usually present at the lower end of the cardiac notch of the left lung.

The right lung has 3 lobes:

  • Superior
  • Middle
  • Inferior

The left lung has 2 lobes:

  • Superior
  • Inferior

Note: The azygos vein may sometimes course in a more lateral position, within a four-layered pleural septum within the superior lobe, creating an ‘azygos lobe’. This is not a true lobe, but a separated portion of the superior lobe that lacks its own bronchi, arteries, or veins.

questions.text: How many bronchopulmonary segments are there in the right and left lungs, respectively?
questions.solution:
Both the lungs have 10 bronchopulmonary segments each.

The functionally independent unit of lung tissue is called a bronchopulmonary segment. Each segment is a separate respiratory unit. 

Some books state 9 segments in the left lung and 10 segments in the right lung as the medial basal segment is fused with the anterior basal segment in the left lung.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male smoker was diagnosed to have carcinoma of the right lung. Bronchogram showed the presence of a tumor, causing partial occlusion of the eparterial bronchus. Which of the following bronchopulmonary segments are likely to receive decreased airflow​?
questions.solution:
The eparterial bronchus supplies the right upper lobe, which includes the segments: apical, posterior, and anterior. Hence, these segments will have decreased airflow.

questions.text: Bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by which of the following bronchi?
questions.solution:
The bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by tertiary bronchi (3°).

Principal bronchi (1°) ---> lobar bronchi (2° - right into 3, left into 2) ---> segmental bronchi (3°)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the bronchopulmonary segment?

choices.text: It is named according to the segmental bronchus supplying it
It is drained by independent intrasegmental branch of pulmonary vein
It is the largest subdivision of a lobe

questions.solution:
The bronchopulmonary segments are not drained by an independent branch of the pulmonary vein.

The tributaries of the pulmonary vein tend to pass intersegmentally between and around the margins of segments.

A bronchopulmonary segment is the area of lung supplied by a segmental bronchus and its accompanying pulmonary artery branch and can be resected surgically. It is the largest division of a lobe.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ED due to choking. Examination showed decreased breath sounds on the right side. An inhaled foreign body lodged in the right bronchus is suspected. Which of the following is not an explanation for this presentation?

choices.text: Right lung is shorter and wider than the left
Right principal bronchus is more vertical than the left bronchus
Tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung
Right inferior lobar bronchus is in continuation with the principal bronchus

questions.solution:
The right principal bronchus (not the right lung) is wider, shorter (2.5 cm), and more vertical than the left. The right inferior lobar bronchus is the continuation of the bronchus intermedius which is in the continuation of the right principal bronchus. These differences explain why inhaled foreign bodies enter the right principal bronchus more often than the left.

The left principal bronchus is narrower, longer (5 cm) and less vertical than the right principal bronchus.

questions.text: Up to which level does the bronchial artery supplies blood to the lungs?
questions.solution:
The bronchial artery supplies the lungs up to the respiratory bronchiole.

Bronchial arteries are derived from the descending thoracic aorta either directly or indirectly. They travel and branch with the bronchi, and terminate around the level of the respiratory bronchioles.

Pulmonary arteries alone perfuse the further distal pathways including the alveolar ducts and the alveoli.
